content.title: Stagflation
content.definition: Stagflation is a macroeconomic condition characterized by the simultaneous occurrence of stagnant economic growth (high unemployment, low or negative GDP growth) and high inflation. The term combines 'stagnation' and 'inflation.' It contradicts the traditional Phillips curve tradeoff which suggested inflation and unemployment move inversely. Stagflation typically results from negative supply shocks (oil price spikes, productivity declines) that shift the short-run aggregate supply curve leftward, raising prices while reducing output. It creates a severe policy dilemma: contractionary policy to fight inflation worsens unemployment, while expansionary policy to reduce unemployment worsens inflation.

definitions_glossary.stagflation: Simultaneous high inflation and high unemployment with stagnant growth - combination of 'stagnation' + 'inflation'
definitions_glossary.supply_shock: Sudden event that shifts SRAS curve - oil embargoes, natural disasters, pandemic disruptions are negative shocks
definitions_glossary.cost_push_inflation: Inflation caused by rising production costs (energy, wages, materials) pushing up prices - supply-side inflation
definitions_glossary.demand_pull_inflation: Inflation caused by excess aggregate demand relative to supply - moving along SRAS curve
definitions_glossary.phillips_curve: Inverse relationship between inflation and unemployment - stagflation showed this only holds for demand shocks
definitions_glossary.aggregate_supply_shock: Event that changes economy's productive capacity or cost structure - shifts SRAS curve
definitions_glossary.opec: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries - orchestrated 1973 and 1979 oil embargoes causing stagflation
definitions_glossary.misery_index: Sum of inflation rate and unemployment rate - peaked at 21% during 1970s stagflation
definitions_glossary.policy_dilemma: Central bank can't simultaneously fight both high inflation and high unemployment when both are elevated
definitions_glossary.accommodation: Expansionary policy response to supply shock - maintains output but validates higher prices into expectations
definitions_glossary.cold_turkey: Contractionary policy response to supply shock - fights inflation but deepens recession
definitions_glossary.expectations_anchor: Stable long-run inflation expectations that prevent supply shock from becoming permanent inflation spiral
definitions_glossary.real_wage_resistance: Workers' resistance to cuts in real purchasing power - prolongs stagflation if nominal wages rise with prices

key_points: Stagflation = high inflation + high unemployment + low growth simultaneously - contradicts simple Phillips curve
Caused by negative supply shocks: SRAS shifts left → higher prices AND lower output at same time
1970s oil crises: 1973 OPEC embargo (oil 4× higher) and 1979 Iranian revolution (oil 2.5× higher) classic examples
Policy dilemma: Contractionary policy worsens unemployment; expansionary policy worsens inflation
Destroyed belief in stable Phillips curve tradeoff - led to expectations-augmented Phillips curve
In AD-AS model: Negative supply shock shifts SRAS left; AD unchanged → move along AD to higher P, lower Y
Fed accommodation in 1970s: Expansionary response to shocks validated inflation expectations → inflation spiral
Volcker solution (1979-82): Accept recession to break expectations - contractionary policy despite high unemployment
Misery index = inflation + unemployment: Peaked at 21% (1980) vs typical 10-12%
Modern relevance: 2022 supply chain/energy shocks raised stagflation concerns (though less severe than 1970s)

examples.title: 1973-74 OPEC Oil Embargo
examples.description: Arab members of OPEC imposed oil embargo on US and allies supporting Israel in Yom Kippur War. Oil prices quadrupled from $3 to $12/barrel. Massive negative supply shock: production costs soared across economy. SRAS shifted left dramatically. Results: Inflation surged to 12.3% (1974), GDP fell 0.5%, unemployment rose from 4.9% to 8.5% (1975). Classic stagflation - both inflation and unemployment worsened. Fed initially accommodated, then tightened too late.
examples.context: First major stagflation episode - the original oil shock

examples.title: 1979-80 Iranian Revolution and Second Oil Shock
examples.description: Iranian Revolution disrupted oil supplies. Oil prices doubled from $15 to $32/barrel (1979-80). Fed had failed to control inflation expectations from first shock - now starting from 9% inflation. Result: Inflation peaked at 14.8% (1980), unemployment rose to 7.5%, GDP stagnated. Misery index hit 21%. This time, Volcker's Fed chose to break inflation with severe tightening - triggering 1981-82 recession but ultimately ending stagflation.
examples.context: Second oil shock compounding first - peak stagflation
examples.data: Oil: $15 → $32/barrel. Inflation: 14.8% peak (1980). Unemployment: 7.5%. Misery index: 21%

examples.title: UK 1970s Stagflation
examples.description: UK suffered even worse stagflation than US. Oil shock plus powerful trade unions demanding wage increases to match inflation. 'Wage-price spiral': prices rose → workers demanded higher wages → costs rose → prices rose more. Peak: Inflation 24% (1975), unemployment rising. IMF bailout required (1976). Thatcher elected 1979 on anti-inflation platform - pursued tight monetary policy, broke union power. Painful recession but ended stagflation.
examples.data: UK inflation: 24% (1975). Unemployment doubled 1973-76. IMF loan: $3.9 billion (1976). Thatcher reforms from 1979

examples.title: Why 2021-22 Wasn't Full Stagflation
examples.description: Post-COVID: Supply chain disruptions + energy price spikes + strong demand (fiscal stimulus). Inflation surged to 9.1% (June 2022). BUT: Unemployment remained very low (3.5-4%), GDP growth positive. Not true stagflation - demand was strong. Supply shocks without the 'stag' (stagnation) part. Fed raised rates aggressively; inflation fell without major recession (so far). Demonstrates: Supply shock alone doesn't cause stagflation if demand is strong and expectations anchored.
examples.context: Near-miss stagflation - supply shock without stagnation
examples.data: Inflation: 9.1% (June 2022). Unemployment: 3.5-4%. GDP growth: +5.7% (2021), +2.1% (2022). Not stagflation - no stagnation

examples.title: 1970s vs 1990s Oil Price Spikes
examples.description: 1990 Gulf War: Oil prices doubled. But outcome different from 1970s. Fed maintained credibility, inflation expectations anchored. Monetary policy response calibrated. Recession mild (8 months), inflation rose briefly. 1970s: Fed had no credibility, expectations unanchored, accommodation fed inflation spiral. Lesson: Same supply shock, different outcomes based on expectations and policy credibility.
examples.context: Contrasting response to similar shocks - credibility matters
examples.data: 1990: Oil doubled, inflation rose 1.5pp, mild recession. 1970s: Similar shock caused 8pp inflation rise and severe stagflation

content.statement: Stagflation represents one of the most challenging macroeconomic conditions, combining high inflation with high unemployment and stagnant growth. Understanding its causes (supply shocks) and the policy dilemma it creates is essential for analyzing macroeconomic crises and the evolution of monetary policy from the 1970s to today.

explanation.intuition: Imagine the economy as a car. Normally, you can trade off speed (growth) for fuel efficiency (low inflation) - push the accelerator for more speed, less efficiency; ease off for less speed, more efficiency. This is the Phillips curve tradeoff. Stagflation is like having a flat tire AND running out of gas simultaneously. The flat tire (supply shock) means the car can't go fast even if you floor it (expansionary policy). But flooring it also wastes the little gas you have (inflation). You're stuck going slow with poor efficiency. The only solutions are painful: fix the tire (wait for supply to recover) or accept being stranded while you call for help (accept recession to reset expectations).
explanation.key_insight: The crucial insight is that stagflation results from supply shocks, not demand shocks. Traditional demand-side policies assume a tradeoff: stimulate → more inflation, less unemployment; contract → less inflation, more unemployment. Supply shocks break this tradeoff by affecting both inflation and output in the same direction. A negative supply shock raises prices (by increasing costs) AND reduces output (by reducing capacity). Policymakers face a cruel choice: fight inflation with contraction (worsening already-high unemployment) or fight unemployment with expansion (worsening already-high inflation). The 1970s Fed chose accommodation initially - big mistake. Inflation expectations became unanchored, requiring Volcker's brutal recession to reset them. Modern central banks learned: credibility and anchored expectations are crucial for handling supply shocks without stagflation.
explanation.technical_details: In AD-AS model: Negative supply shock shifts SRAS left (from SRAS₁ to SRAS₂). With AD unchanged: New equilibrium at intersection of AD and SRAS₂ has higher P (inflation) and lower Y (stagnation). This is stagflation. In Phillips curve terms: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε. Adverse supply shock: ε > 0. This shifts short-run Phillips curve up - higher inflation at every unemployment rate. If central bank accommodates (expands AD to maintain Y): inflation rises, expectations rise (πᵉ ↑), curve shifts up again. Spiral. If central bank contracts (shifts AD left to fight inflation): unemployment rises further. Recession. Optimal response depends on expectations anchoring: well-anchored → accept temporary inflation bump, don't overreact. Unanchored → may need contraction to re-anchor.

mathematical_formulation.sras_shift: SRAS: Y = Y* + α(P - Pᵉ). Supply shock: Y = Y* + α(P - Pᵉ) - ε where ε > 0 is adverse shock
mathematical_formulation.ad_unchanged: AD: Y = f(P) with f'(P) < 0 (downward sloping)
mathematical_formulation.new_equilibrium: Solve shifted SRAS = AD: Higher P*, lower Y* compared to before shock
mathematical_formulation.phillips_curve_shock: π = πᵉ - β(u - uⁿ) + ε. With ε > 0: higher π at same u, or higher u at same π target
mathematical_formulation.misery_index: MI = π + u. Stagflation: both π and u elevated → high MI
mathematical_formulation.accommodation_spiral: If central bank maintains Y at Y*: must accept higher P → πᵉ rises → SRAS shifts up again → need more expansion → spiral
mathematical_formulation.disinflation_cost: If central bank targets lower π: must accept Y < Y* → u > uⁿ → recession

accommodation.action: Expansionary policy to offset output loss from supply shock
accommodation.outcome: Maintains output but validates higher prices into inflation expectations
accommodation.risk: If repeated, creates inflation spiral as expectations keep rising
accommodation.1970s_experience: Fed accommodated oil shocks → inflation expectations unanchored → stagflation persisted

cold_turkey.action: Contractionary policy to fight inflation despite high unemployment
cold_turkey.outcome: Breaks inflation expectations but deepens recession temporarily
cold_turkey.benefit: Restores credibility, re-anchors expectations for future stability
cold_turkey.volcker_experience: Raised rates to 20% → recession → broke inflation → 1983 recovery with low inflation

do_nothing.action: Wait for supply shock to reverse, maintain neutral policy
do_nothing.outcome: Works if shock temporary and expectations well-anchored
do_nothing.risk: If expectations unanchored or shock persistent, inflation may persist
do_nothing.requires: Credible central bank with anchored expectations

historical_significance.ended_keynesian_consensus: Phillips curve breakdown forced rethinking of activist demand management
historical_significance.validated_friedman_phelps: Expectations-augmented Phillips curve explained stagflation theoretically
historical_significance.central_bank_credibility: Showed importance of inflation expectations and credibility in policy
historical_significance.supply_side_economics: Attention shifted to supply-side factors (productivity, regulation, taxes)
historical_significance.modern_lessons: Fed learned: don't accommodate supply shocks repeatedly; maintain credibility

concepts: Policy credibility: Central bank independence and inflation fighting
Electoral consequences: Carter defeated partly due to stagflation
Geopolitics: Oil embargoes as political weapons

Volcker era: Transformation of monetary policy
OPEC power: Geopolitical shifts in energy
Cost management: Dealing with input price spikes

Energy strategy: Reducing oil dependence after shocks
